channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Revolutionize and Democratize the Job Recruitment Game
item.description: An Irvine, California-based software company is looking for developers to help revolutionize and democratize the job recruitment game. If youâ€™re proficient in Perl and enthusiastic about other platforms, such as React or Angular on front-end and Node.js or Python on backend, this could be your opportunity to streamline the job market by helping recruiters make better decisions about candidates.

item.title: Sick of jobs lacking purpose? This Perl job literally cures the worldâ€™s ills
item.description: The company is looking for modern Perl developers with a strong interest in Python. You wonâ€™t just be showing off your skills, youâ€™ll be able to expand and build upon them too. Fancy putting your good genes to use in one of Englandâ€™s smartest, most beautiful cities? Want a role that has a tremendously positive impact on society? Get in touch, and letâ€™s get you making a difference.

item.title: Do one thing, do it well, and do it with Perl (US)
item.description: Whenâ€™s the last time you worked someplace for decades? Our client, nestled in charming Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, has a lot of programmers who meet that criterion. Why? Itâ€™s simply a wonderful home for programmers. Theyâ€™re a shop with focus, and devoted to Perl â€“ and only Perl.

item.title: Save the world then go get piste -- Mid-level Perl developer and ski-master in Sevenoaks, Kent
item.description: The company helps charities fundraise online and works in online payments; youâ€™ll literally be saving the world a little bit with every line of code you commit. And while youâ€™ll be well rewarded in financial terms, youâ€™re also likely to enjoy the annual ski trip for the companyâ€™s developers, or popping over to South Africa to work from the offices there.

item.title: Do you love customers? Senior Perl Developer with a product focus, London
item.description: Ever find yourself wishing you could see meaningful impact on users from your work? Trapped in a company with long release cycles and dubious release dates? Wish your ideas for product improvement didnâ€™t keep disappearing in to the Project Managerâ€™s backlog?

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge W024 - Smallest Script, Inverted Index
item.description: Yet, although had no prior knowledge of Inverted Index, made it easy to follow solution. Great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 24
item.description: Roger made the Inverted Index task so simple by breaking into smaller chunk.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge # 24: Smallest Script and Inverted Index
item.description: Laurent once again, shared deep analysis of Inverted Index. Highly Recommended.

item.title: Perl is Good for Nothing
item.description: Joelle being the first to submit the solution to task #1 of Perl Weekly Challenge - 024. She shared an old blog that discuss the similar task. A very interesting take.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 024: Inverted Index and Shortest Oneliner
item.description: Choroba last minute blog is worth it as he used Perl structure instead of database to solve Inverted Index task. Must Read.

item.title: Small Inversions with Perl 6
item.description: You are going to love the solution to task #1 by Arne. He simply killed it.

item.title: Inverted Index Formatting
item.description: The best part of Adam's blog is his detailed explanation of his solution.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 024
item.description: Review of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: berrybrew, the Perlbrew for Windows v1.26 released
item.description: Steve shares summary of the new features for berrybrew.

item.title: #424 - Twin Events
item.description:
Hi there

Two events waiting to happen soon next month. I am very excited about both "Hacktoberfest" and "London Perl Workshop - 2019". As you all know, Hacktoberfest, starts on the 1st October and continues till the end of the month. During this time, you are expected to submit at least 4 Pull Request. In return you earn a limited edition T-shirt delivered to your doorstep for FREE, courtesy DigitalOcean. You can find more information about the event, here.

The second event that I am looking forward to is "London Perl Workshop - 2019". This time, it is happening a little earlier than usual i.e. Saturday 19th October 2019. There is a change in venue as well, this year it is happening at David Game College, 31 Jewry St, London EC3N 2ET. They are still accepting talks, If you have anything interesting to talk about then please submit your talk now. If you are keen to sponsor the event, then please take a look at Sponsorship levels. Looking forward to see you all guys there.

Enjoy rest of the week.
